title-group.article-title: Chaotification and optimization design of a nonlinear vibration isolation system

article-meta.aff: State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, College of Mechanical and Vehicle Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha, P. R. China

author-notes.corresp: Yingli Li, State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body, College of Mechanical and Vehicle Engineering, Hunan University, Changsha 410082, P. R. China Email: liyingli298@yahoo.com

permissions.copyright-statement: © The Author(s) 2011 Reprints and permissions: sagepub.co.uk/journalsPermissions.nav

abstract.p: In this paper, the chaos method for reducing line spectra of the radiated noise of marine vessels is implemented with the application of a control scheme, that is, chaotifing the nonlinear vibration isolation system (VIS) with an external chaotic system, such as the Lorenz system families. The scheme is similar to generalized synchronization of chaos to a considerable degree. Moreover, an implicit performance-index function and optimization strategy are proposed to obtain the optimal control gain for generating chaos with the highest quality. Numerical simulations are carried out and the results confirm the validity and effectiveness of the methods.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: Controlling chaos generally means suppression of chaos when it is harmful. Over the last two decades, chaos has been found to be useful with great potential in many technological disciplines, such as information and computer sciences, biomedical engineering, power systems, flow dynamics and liquid mixing, encryption and communications, etc. Therefore, generating chaos has grown up to as an interesting and challenging research direction in recent years.

The vibration isolation performance of the nonlinear vibration isolator in the chaotic states was found to be much better than that in the nonchaotic vibration states. Liu et al. (2004) took advantage of chaotic vibration isolation to eliminate the periodic component in waterborne noise and to improve the concealment capability of warships. The influence of hard stiffness nonlinearity on the performance of nonlinear isolators was numerically studied by Yu et al. (2003). Yu et al. (2004) also conducted numerical and experimental investigations to evaluate the performance of a nonlinear vibration isolation system (VIS) under chaotic state. They found that the nonlinear isolator exhibits excellent performance and can reduce the line spectrum when the system operates under chaotic state. The spectra of the radiated waterborne noises of marine vessels were constituted of a broad-band noise having a continuous spectrum superimposed on a line spectrum. At high speed, the signature was found to be dominated by a broad-band noise, while at low speed the signature was dominated by a line spectrum (Lou et al., 2005). For soft spring nonlinearity, both amplitude and transmissibility of displacement were found to outperform those observed in hard spring nonlinearity (Zhou et al., 2005).

Yu et al. (2007) used the driving signal of a typical single-degree-of-freedom (dof) oscillator to chaotify the nonlinear VIS. However, the parameter region for chaos of a single-dof oscillator is limited, and the signal is not so stable when a tiny change happens to the oscillator. The Lorenz families’ systems can easily be generated with circuits. Research on chaotification with driving of the Lorenz families has not been reported yet. On the other hand, when the control gain is too small or too large, the aim of reducing line spectra cannot be reached. Hence, selection of the control is of great significance, which determines whether the vibration can be suppressed and how much it can be decreased. As a result, an appropriate optimization strategy is needed here.

In this paper, the chaos method for reducing line spectra of the radiated noise of marine vessels is implemented with the application of a control scheme, that is, chaotifing the nonlinear VIS with the Lorenz system families. The scheme is similar to generalized synchronization of chaos. Moreover, an implicit performance-index function and optimization strategy are proposed to obtain the optimal control gain for generating chaos with the highest quality. Numerical simulations are carried out and the results confirm the validity and effectiveness of the methods.

sec.title: 2. Governing equations
sec.p:
The nonlinear VIS can be considered as a two-dof mass-spring system (Yu et al., 2007), as shown in Figure 1. M1 and M2 denote the isolated equipment and the base, respectively. M1 is supported by a vibration isolator combining a linear damper and a nonlinear spring that possess quadric and cubic nonlinearity. M2 is connected with a fixed plane using a linear damper and a linear spring, which is much harder than the nonlinear spring. In addition, there is an actuator between M1 and M2, which is utilized to implement control of generalized chaos synchronization. Figure 1.
Basic model.

When the origins of coordinates are set at the places where the springs are not compressed, as shown in Figure 1(a), the equation of the two-dof nonlinear spring-mass system can be given by (1)M1X··1+C1(X·1-X·2)+K1(X1-X2)-U1(X1-X2)2 +U2(X1-X2)3=FcosΩT+M1gM2X··2+C2X·2+K2X2=C1(X·1-X·2)+K1(X1-X2) -U1(X1-X2)2+U2(X1-X2)3+M2g where M1 is the mass of the isolated equipment; M2 is the mass of the base; C1 is the damping coefficient of the nonlinear vibration isolator; K1, U1 and U2 are the linear, quadric and cubic stiffness coefficients of the nonlinear vibration isolator, respectively; C2 is the damping coefficient of the damper between the base and fixed plane; K2 is the stiffness coefficient of the linear spring between the base and the fixed plane; and F and Ω are the amplitude and frequency of the harmonic excitation, respectively.

Note that the origins are not the equilibrium points of this system, which is inconvenient in further analyses, and so the coordinate transformation should be carried out. As shown in Figure 1(b), the origins of the new coordinates are located at the equilibrium places of these springs, that is, the places where these springs are compressed, and the relations between the old and new coordinates are (2)X1=Z1+h1, X2=Z2+h2

When the system is in the equilibrium state, the following relations can be used to eliminate the gravitation terms from the right-hand side of the equations of motion: (3)K1H-U1H2+U2H3=M1gK2h2=M1g+M2g where H=h1-h2.

After the coordinate transformation, the governing equations based on generalized synchronization concept are (4)M1Z··1=-C1(Z·1-Z·2)-(K1-2U1H+3U2H2+Pv) (Z1-Z2)+(U1-3U2H)(Z1-Z2)2 -U2(Z1-Z2)3+FcosΩTM2Z··2=-C2Z·2-K2Z2+C1(Z·1-Z·2) +(K1-2U1H+3U2H2+Pv)(Z1-Z2) -(U1-3U2H)(Z1-Z2)2+U2(Z1-Z2)3 where P is the control gain of the actuator and v is the signal from the driving system.

Introducing dimensionless parameters: (5)x1=Z1B,x2=Z2B,Ω0=M1K1-2U1H+3U2H2,B=K1-2U1H+3U2H2U2,T=Ω0t,ω1=ΩΩ0,μ=M1M2,δ1=C1M1(K1-2U1H+3U2H2),δ2=C2M1(K1-2U1H+3U2H2),ξ1=B(U1-3U2H)K1-2U1H+3U2H2,f=FB(K1-2U1H+3U2H2),k2=K2K1-2U1H+3U2H2,p=PB(K1-2U1H+3U2H2) and substituting Equations (5) into Equations (4), the first-order form of the dimensionless motion equations are given by (6)x·1=y1y·1=-δ1(y1-y2)-(1+pv)(x1-x2)+ξ1(x1-x2)2 -(x1-x2)3+fcosω1tx·2=y2y·2=-δ2μy2-μk2x2+μδ1(y1-y2) +μ(1+pv)(x1-x2)-ξ1μ(x1-x2)2+μ(x1-x2)3
In the absence of drive, system (6) is just the same as the equations of motion in the lead article (Yu et al., 2007).
When p = 0, the associated autonomous system of system (5) possesses three equilibrium points: (7)A(0,0,0,0),B(12ξ1+12ξ12-4,0,0,0),C(12ξ1-12ξ12-4,0,0,0)

However, for a practical nonlinear VIS, B and C are impossible because the relation between load and displacement is a monotone function and the curve of stiffness of the nonlinear spring has no chance to intersect the displacement axis more than two times. The free vibration of the nonlinear VIS in some initial conditions will attenuate to the only equilibrium point A.

sec.title: 3. Control scheme
sec.p: At present, an increasing number of researchers realize that sometimes chaotic behavior and chaos synchronization are beneficial and desirable in many applications. For this purpose, making a nonchaotic dynamical system chaotic or retaining (or enhancing) the chaos of a chaotic system is called ‘anti-control of chaos’ or ‘chaotification’. The primary chaotification schemes for a nonlinear dynamical system include feedback control (Saha et al., 2003; Chen and Lee, 2004; Wang and Chau, 2008), adaptive control (Zhang et al., 2004; Ge and Lee, 2005), switching piecewise-linear control (Lü and Chen, 2002; Zheng et al., 2004), and so on. Among these methods, feedback control is the most popular method because of its simple configuration and easy implementation.

For generating chaos in the nonlinear VIS of onboard machinery, the feedback scheme means that the execute components should be connected with the isolated equipment or the base directly, and hence have to consume considerable energy and bring into vibration the marine vessels. In this paper, the execute components are mounted between the isolated equipment and the base, but not on the marine vessels directly. The control schemes are selected as the Lorenz system families.

sec.title: 3.1. The driving chaotic system is selected as a Lorenz system
sec.p: The regular Lorenz system is (8)x·=a(y-x)y·=cx-xz-yz·=xy-bz

When a=10,b=8/3,c=28 for the above Lorenz system and the initial condition is set as (1, 1, 1), the chaotic attractors are as shown in Figure 2(a). The response x is chosen as the driving signal v. Figure 2.
Phase portraits of (a) the Lorenz system, (b) the Chen system, (c) the Lü system, (d) the Rössler system and (e) the Chua system.

sec.title: 3.2. The driving chaotic system is selected as a Chen system
sec.p: The regular Chen system is (9)x·=a(y-x)y·=(c-a)x-xz+cyz·=xy-bz
When a=35,b=3,c=28 for the above Chen system and the initial condition is set as (1, 1, 1), the chaotic attractors are as shown in Figure 2(b). The response x is chosen as the driving signal v.

sec.title: 3.3. The driving chaotic system is selected as a Lü system
sec.p: The regular Lü system is (10)x·=a(y-x)y·=-xz+cyz·=xy-bz
When a=36,b=3,c=20 for the above Lü system and the initial condition is set as (1, 1, 1), the chaotic attractors are as shown in Figure 2(c). The response x is chosen as the driving signal v.

sec.title: 3.4. The driving chaotic system is selected as a Rössler system
sec.p: The Rössler system is (11)x·=-(y+z)y·=x+ayz·=z(x-c)+b

When a=0.2,b=0.2,c=5.7 for the above Rössler system and the initial condition is set as (1, 1, 1), the chaotic attractors are as shown in Figure 2(d). The response x is chosen as the driving signal v.

sec.title: 3.5. The driving chaotic system is selected as a Chua system
sec.p: The dimensionless Chua system is (12)x·=r(-x+y-f(x))y·=x-y+zz·=-qy where f(x)=m~0x+12(m~1-m~0)(|x+1|-|x-1|).

When r=10,q=14.87,m~0=-0.68,m~1=-1.27, for the above Chua system and the initial condition is set as (2, 0, 0), the chaotic attractors are as shown in Figure 2(e). The response x is chosen as the driving signal v.

sec.title: 4. Optimization with the performance index
sec.p: In order to make the system chaos with the best quality, we attempt to find the optimal control gain to minimize the maximum amplitude of the line spectra. The performance index is proposed to characterize the chaotification quality, which can be expressed as (13)Minimize I=Amax=max{20lg[∑i=1Nx2(i)e-2πj(k-1)(i-1)/N]},k=1,2,…,N where Amax is the maximum amplitude of the logarithmic power spectrum of the base M2, j is the imaginary unit -1 and x(i) is the time history of displacement of the base M2. It is well known that the analytical solution of the governing equations is difficult to obtain. Hence, there is no explicit expression for the performance index. However, the index is dependent on the system parameters sensitively. In this paper, only one design variable is considered, that is the control gain p, in the range of [0, 10].

As the performance index changes radically with the control gain increasing, the optimization methods based on gradient will be unable to settle this problem, and the nongradient method should be adopted. Hooke and Jeeves’ method is a type of direct search method that has been widely used.

It is worth noting that the optimal control gain obtained by Hooke and Jeeves’ method is a local optimum strongly depending on the initial guess. In order to find the global optimum, some global optimization methods, for example, the Genetic Algorithm and Simulated Algorithm, should be used. However, those algorithms are computationally expensive. Therefore, there is a conflict between computational accuracy and efficiency. Hooke and Jeeves’ method can be used to obtain the optimum or quasi-optimum with the aid of careful choices of initial guess and step size. Moreover, for the system with unknown parameters, the objective function is obtained based on the experimental time history, and it is in urgent need of optimization numerical techniques with high computational efficiency to find the optimal control gain as quickly as possible. Therefore, Hooke and Jeeves’ method is adopted in this paper.

sec.title: 5. Numerical simulations
sec.p: The following numerical simulations demonstrate and verify the effectiveness of the proposed control schemes and optimization method. The fourth-order Runge–Kutta method is used to integrate the differential equations with time step 0.01. The dimensionless parameters of the nonlinear VIS are set as (I)δ1=0.2,δ2=0.2,ξ1=1,f=20,μ=0.2,k2=2,ω1=3.9311(II)δ1=0.21355,δ2=0.21355,ξ1=0.00607665,f=83.563,μ=2,k2=530.285,ω1=3.9311

The dimensionless parameters of (I) are the parameters taken by Yu et al. (2007) in the numerical simulation. In dimensionless parameters of (II), the disk spring is used as the nonlinear isolator, which possesses linear, quadric and cubic stiffness.

Eigenvalues at the equilibrium point A of system (I) without driving are {−0.123078 + 1.12886i, −0.123078 − 1.12886i, −0.0169221 + 0.556705i, −0.0169221 − 0.556705i}. The eigenvalues for system (II) are {−0.427493 + 32.5929i, −0.427493 − 32.5929i, −0.106382 + 0.99342i, −0.106382 - 0.99342i}. As all the eigenvalues of the Jacobian matrix possess negative real parts at the zero solution, so the system (1) is asymptotic stable.

Figure 3 show that the nonlinear VIS takes on a periodic motion when p=0 and with dimensionless parameters of (I), and the line spectrum at the primary frequency ω1=3.9311 is −0.2361. The agreements in Figures 3(a)–(c) ensure the validity of the computing method in this study. The difference between the amplitudes of the line spectra in Figure 3(d) and the result in the pioneer work (Yu et al., 2007) is owing to the different methods of calculation for the power spectrum. Figure 3.
Dynamic behaviors of the nonlinear vibration isolation system in the uncontrolled state with parameters of (I): (a) time history of the displacement of isolated equipment M1; (b) time history of the displacement of the base M2; (c) phase portrait of the base M2; (d) power spectrum of the base M2.

When the driving signal is an output of a Lorenz system and p=5, the continuous power spectrum of the base M2, which indicates chaotic motion, is as shown in Figure 4(a). It is obvious that the maximum line spectrum is −10.45 at the primary frequency ω1=3.9311, which is much less than the value in the uncontrolled state. The change of the performance index with the increase of the control gain is presented in Figure 4(b). It can be seen that the performance index is rather sensitive to the variation of the control gain. Figure 4(c) illustrates the power spectrum of the base M2 with the driving signal from a Lorenz system, when p is set as the optimal value 7. One can find that the line spectrum at the primary frequency ω1=3.9311 is −11.88, which is even less than the value in Figure 4(a). Figure 4.
Dynamic behaviors of the base M2 of system (I) controlled with the driving signal from a Lorenz system: (a) power spectrum of the base M2 with p = 5; (b) objective function as a function of control gain p; (c) power spectrum of the base M2 with the optimal control gain p.

Figures 5(a)–(d) present power spectra of the base M2 of system (II) with the corresponding optimal control gain p and control signal from the Chen system, Lü system, Rössler system and Chua system, respectively. The optimal control gain p for the Chen system is 9.7 and the line spectrum for p at the primary frequency ω1=3.9311 is –11.97, which is much less than the value in the uncontrolled state. When p is set as the optimal value 5.7, the line spectra is mostly reduced to −11.34 with the driving signal from a Lü system. The most decrements of line spectra of the nonlinear VIS controlled by a Rössler system and a Chua system are −4.82 and −3.014, with p = 6.05 and 5.7, respectively. It can be concluded that the Lorenz system, Chen system and Lü system are more effective than the Rössler system and Chua system due to the reduction of line spectra of the nonlinear VIS. Figure 5.
Power spectrum of the base M2 of system (I) controlled with the corresponding optimal control gains p by (a) the Chen system, (b) the Lü system, (c) the Rössler system and (d) the Chua system.

The dynamic behaviors of the nonlinear VIS in the uncontrolled state with dimensionless parameters of (II) are presented in Figure 6. It can be seen that the nonlinear VIS without drive takes on a periodic motion, and the line spectrum at the primary frequency is −9.162. Moreover, the vibration amplitude of the base M2 is much less than the isolated equipment M1 by comparison of Figures 6(a) and (b). It is indicated that the effect of passive isolation with the disk spring outperforms the isolator only with cubic nonlinearity. Figure 6.
Dynamic behaviors of the nonlinear vibration isolation system in the uncontrolled state with parameters of (II): (a) time history of the displacement of isolated equipment M1; (b) time history of the displacement of the base M2; (c) phase portrait of the base M2; (d) power spectrum of the base M2.

Power spectra of the base M2 of system (II) with the control signals from different systems and the corresponding optimal control gains are presented in Figure 7. When p is set as the optimal value 7.95 and the Lorenz system is selected as the driving system, the line spectrum at the primary frequency ω1=3.9311 is −13.41, as shown in Figure 7(a), which is less than the value in the uncontrolled state. Figure 7(b) shows the power spectrum of the base M2 with the driving signal from a Chen system, when p is set as the optimal value 9.35. It can be seen that the line spectrum at the primary frequency is −12.83. Taking p as the optimal value 8.75, the power spectrum of the base M2 with the driving signal from a Lü system is as shown in Figure 7(c), and the line spectrum at ω1=3.9311 is −13.28. The most decrements of line spectra of the nonlinear VIS (II) controlled by a Rössler system and a Chua system with p = 9.8 and 9.55, respectively, are −11.3 and −10.01. For the nonlinear VIS (II), the Lorenz system, Chen system and Lü system are more effective than the Rössler system and Chua system as well. Figure 7.
Power spectrum of the base M2 of system (II) controlled with the corresponding optimal control gains p by (a) the Lorenz system, (b) the Chen system, (c) the Lü system, (d) the Rössler system and (e) the Chua system.

sec.title: 6. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper, using the external driving signal from the Lorenz system families to drive the nonlinear VIS is presented to generate persistent chaos in the nonlinear system, and we use the chaos method for reducing the linear spectrum. Furthermore, an optimization strategy is proposed to obtain the optimal control gain for generating chaos with the highest quality.

Numerical simulations are carried out to confirm the validity and effectiveness of this method. The results show that the nonlinear VIS possesses an excellent isolation performance of vibration and line spectra by utilizing this method. The effect of passive isolation with the disk spring, which possesses quadric and cubic nonlinearity, outperforms the isolator only with cubic nonlinearity. The control schemes of Lorenz system families can reduce the line spectra significantly with the moderate control gain, which can be selected by Hooke and Jeeves’ method effectively. Moreover, the Lorenz system, Chen system and Lü system are more effective than the Rössler system and Chua system for the reduction of line spectra of the nonlinear VIS.

ack.p: The authors would like to thank Professor Shijian Zhu for his sincere help and support.

sec.p: This work was supported by the Chaos-Based Isolation Technology (grant number 799215116) and the State Key Laboratory of Advanced Design and Manufacturing for Vehicle Body (grant number 71075004).
